thread.title: Upper Arlington handles Sycamore in state final, 11-6
thread.title_full: Upper Arlington handles Sycamore in state final, 11-6

title: Upper Arlington handles Sycamore in state final, 11-6
text:
Upper Arlington handles Sycamore in state final, 11-6 Nicholas Robbe , nrobbe@communitypress.com 10:01 p.m. EDT October 24, 2015 Buy Photo Princeton's Dana Collopy takes aim at the goal against Sylvania. The Vikings finished the tournament in 10th place. Nick Robbe/Community Press Kiera Jackson looks to pass the ball ahead to a teammate. Nick Robbe/Community Press Paige Wantlin readies for a shot. Nick Robbe/Community Press Viking captain Hannah Rust looks to pass ahead to a teammate. Nick Robbe/Community Press Isabelle Hoard escapes pressure from a Sylvania defender. Nick Robbe/Community Press Katie Hiles jumps to block a shot, which eventually sailed wide of the net. Nick Robbe/Community Press Milford coach Kevin Metzger talks with his team prior to the game. Nick Robbe/Community Press Milford's Skyler Fontaine before she takes a shot on net. Nick Robbe/Community Press Buy Photo Milford's Alison McClure (5) and Hayley Steffy chase the ball after closing down on the Mason shooter. Nick Robbe/Community Press Hayley Steffy looks for an open shot. Nick Robbe/Community Press Emily Noll gets a hand on a shot from a Mason attacker. Nick Robbe/Community Press Elyse Flannery looks for an open teammate while under pressure. Nick Robbe/Community Press Mason's Sydney Sinchek tries to create space against Milford. Nick Robbe/Community Press Comet keeper Melissa Nguyen gets in position to block a shot. Nick Robbe/Community Press Mason coach Kent Rasmussen talks with his team during a timeout. Nick Robbe/Community Press Olivia Bunton (7) gets tied up with a Milford defender. Nick Robbe/Community Press Jenna Steinbicker (15) applies pressure to Milford's Skyler Fontaine. Nick Robbe/Community Press Mason's Camille Nguyen fights for a shot in traffic. Nick Robbe/Community Press Sycamore's Abigail Hausfeld looks for a teammate to pass to. Nick Robbe/Community Press Sycamore's Hannah Kast, right, attempts to steal the ball. Nick Robbe/Community Press Jessica Wei looks for open teammates. Nick Robbe/Community Press Hannah May looks for an open shot. Nick Robbe/Community Press Jory Gould (18) fights for position in the fourth quarter. NIck Rpbbe/Community Press Sycamore players show off the state runner-up trophy to their fans. Nick Robbe/Community Press Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Sycamore's Hannah Kast, right, attempts to steal the ball. (Photo: Nick Robbe/Community Press) Buy Photo 2 CONNECT 10 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
COLUMBUS Riding a comeback win against Mason earlier in the day, Sycamore's girls water polo team came out energized in the state final game Saturday at Ohio Wesleyan University. 
The Aviators took a 4-1 lead against Upper Arlington, last year's state champion. However, they couldn't maintain the pace once they had poked the Bears. 
UA scored nine unanswered goals to take a 10-4 lead before closing Sycamore out 11-6. 
"For three quarters of the game, it went exactly how I thought it would go," Sycamore coach Nicholas Hellwig said. "We came out fired up, ready to go. We played the game we needed to in those three quarters. Against top teams, you can't give up a bad quarter. Six goals in the third quarter is hard to come back from." 
Early on in the game, the Aviators' passes were crisp, allowing them to set up their offense and bury shots in the back of the net. 
But as the game wore on, the Aviators started turning the ball over and fatigue began to take its toll. That allowed the Bears to go on the offensive. 
"They live on that counter-attack," Hellwig said. "We could get to their first and second girl but we couldn't account for the third and fourth girl. That's where they beat us. That extra line through." 
Even though the rough ending to a good season wasn't what Hellwig and his team imagined, he said he wouldn't change a thing. 
"It's been fantastic," he said. "31 wins in a season is amazing. We were one short of the (school) record but I don't care. I'd give anything for them to have this season again." 
In other state tournament action, Milford defeated Mason 10-9 in double overtime to finish in fifth place. The Comets finished sixth overall. 
Milford held a 7-6 lead with 32 seconds remaining in the fourth period when Mason called a timeout. After the restart, the timekeeper didn't start the clock. 
Amidst the consternation, the Comets scored to tie the game. 
In the extra periods, the Eagles hung on to secure the victory. 
"Table errors happen in any big match," Milford head coach Kevin Metzger said. "All we can do when that happens is adapt, come back and win like we did. At the beginning of the year, we thought we had a really, really young team. From day one, they kept growing and figuring each other out. I couldn't have asked for a better turnout. We kept up with some of the top teams in the state. " 
Earlier in the day, Princeton battled Sylvania in the ninth-place match. The Vikings fell 14-7, finishing in 10th place. 2 CONNECT 10 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://cin.ci/1S3t9nB TOP VIDEOS
